What Is "Hello" in C++? - Nicolai M. Josuttis - ACCU 2025 Short Talks
---

What is "hello" in C++ - really? This lightning talk dives deep into the nature of string literals in C++, exploring the value category of "hello", how type deduction works, and why it's more complex than it appears at first glance.

Many C++ developers assume they understand the basics of a string literal, but in this talk, we challenge that assumption. Using the example "hello", we walk through how C++ interprets it in terms of type and value category — is it a const char array? A PR value? An Lvalue? We’ll find out using tools like `decltype`, `auto`, and references.

You’ll learn:
- What a C++ string literal really is at the type system level.
- How value categories (Lvalue, Rvalue, PRvalue, Xvalue) affect interpretation.
- Why `decltype("hello")` may not return what you expect.
- How array decay, type deduction, and move semantics play a role.
- The differ
title: What Is "Hello" in C++? - Nicolai M. Josuttis - ACCU 2025 Short Talks
